p: Khan and Roberts (2013) analyze the rise of adaptation agenda from its unsteady foundation in the 1990s, arguing that three factors drove this shift: (i) an increase in climate disasters in recent years, which sharpened the cognitive frame of climate justice; (ii) no ambitious mitigation, so to mollify developing country sentiments, industrial countries made concrete proposals of climate finance in Copenhagen; and (iii) inclusion of the agenda of` Loss and Damage (L&D), adding a new momentum in adaptation policy. But this ascent is not translated into adequate, new, additional, and predictable finance.
